description.narrative:
The main purpose of the paper is to inform the development of an advocacy strategy focusing on engagement with Parliamentarians that will contribute to policy influencing on food, population and climate justice issues in five select countries of South Asia.
The planned meeting will be the preparatory meeting to set up the Forum which aims to contribute to the outcome of building movements toshare good policies and practices at South Asia level resulting in improved national level policy processes related to climate change and legislation of the Right to Food (linking land rights and water). One way to achieve this is through engaging with formal power structures by forming and scaling up alliances with Members of Parliament (Parliamentarians) from country up to regional level. ARegional Forum of Parliamentarians in South Asia will be set up later on to promote joint lobby and advocacy with key Members of Parliament (MPs) from different SA countries and linkage to civil society. -- The Study is a preparation for the Parliamentarian Forum, which would help people affected by food insecurity, climate change and land grabs in South Asia to have a say - through the improved relations between the NGOs, CSOs representing their rights and the Parliamentarians - in the preparation and implementation of new national laws related to different areas of the GROW campaign
- Experiences shared from each country at a regional level will support new ways of reaching government and policy makers to achieve GROW objectives in the other countries

participating-org.narrative: AFPPD is recognized by UN as a pioneer in parliamentary action. In 2010, AFPPD was endowed the United Nations Population Award. It was remarked by Dr. Asha-Rose Migiro, Deputy Secretary General of the UN that AFPPD has successfully pushed for legislation on the elimination of violence against women and on the full spectrum of population issues, including AIDS, reproductive health, family planning, ageing, gender equality, and empowerment of women. AFPPD has played an active role in raising parliamentarians# awareness and knowledge on population and development issues and has enhance their capacity to advocate for these issues in Parliament. In 2012, the Philippines passed its controversial Reproductive Health Bill authored by our then Deputy Secretary General Edcel Lagman. AFPPD#sNational Committee in the Philippines was very instrumental in mobilizing legislators, civil society organizations, the media and other stakeholders to support the bill. At the recently concluded Sixth Asian Pacific Parliamentarians Conference, champion parliamentarians mobilized by AFPPD particularly the Pacific played a crucial role in ensuring contentious SRHR issues are included in the outcome document adopted by 47 countries in the region. Witnessing the human faces of adverse population and development issues, the study visit inspired the establishment of Asian Forum of Parliamentarians on Population and Development (AFPPD) was founded in 1981 in Beijing, China to recognize the role of parliamentarians as key partners in addressing these issues given their unique capacity tocraft and revise legislation, approve budgets and policy oversight. Mission: To strengthen capacity of existing National Committeesand their Secretariats by increasing awareness and promoting the understanding of the interrelationships between population and development related issues; initiating, promoting and supporting training and exchange programmes to encourage new and effective ideas and approaches to population and development issues; promoting a continuing dialogue between parliamentarians, and social, economic,health, population and development planners, implementers and other stakeholders at all levels; and facilitating the dissemination and utilisation of information and research including print and online resources, to promote policy solutions to population and development issues. Institutional objectives: Encourage and promote parliamentary and related activities to obtain government and publicsupport aimed at facilitating population and development policies designed to meet the needs and improve the living standards of the people in Asia and the Pacific, with a view to contributing to the achievement of equitable and sustainable development and lasting world peace. Fields of activity: We have 27 National Committees all over Asia and the Pacific including Central Asia. Our member countries include: Afghanistan, Australia, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, India, Indonesia, Iran, Japan, Kazakhstan, South Korea, Kyrgyztan, Lao PDR, Malaysia, Maldives, Mongolia, Nepal, New Zealand, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Pacific Islands, Sri Lanka, Tajikistan, Thailand, Timor Leste, and Vietnam. Our main actors are Ministers, Senators and Members of Parliament from these 27 member countries. In addition, Bhutan and Myanmar are also active associate members.
Asian Forum of Parliamentarians on Population & Development
